title: Week 1, Lab 1: Swirl
text:
To start becoming familiar with R, we’re going to complete some interactive, self-paced lessons using swirl.
Steps:

Open up RStudio, type the following in the console pane (next to the > symbol), and press Enter. This should install the ‘swirl’ package for R. That means the package files have been downloaded and saved to your computer.


install.packages("swirl")


But to actually use the functions in the swirl package, we need to load the package into our current R session. We do this using the library() function, providing it the name of the package that we want to load.


library("swirl")


Enter the following command to install an introductory course called “R_Programming_E” (admittedly, not the greatest name).


install_course_github("swirldev", "R_Programming_E")


Okay! We’re ready to run the course. Enter the following:


swirl()


When prompted (after a few screens), choose the lesson called “Basic Building Blocks”.

title: Week 5, Lab 1: Late quaternary mammals
text:
Description of data set
These data were originally published as a “data paper” in the journal Ecology by Felisa Smith and colleagues (2003). It provides the body mass of mammal species from the Late Quaternary period of earth’s history, which is defined here as beginning “as approximately 11 ka for Africa, North and South America, and as 50 ka for Australia, because these times predate anthropogenic impacts on mammalian fauna,” up to and including the present day. The data were updated in 2016 and can be found in the repository linked below (Smith et al., 2016).



Thylacoleo carnifex, my 8-year old son Leo’s favorite late Pleistocene mammal, which went extinct about 30 ka in an absolute tragedy. Image credit: Peter Schouten.

title: Week 2, Lab 1: Markdown CV
text:
Complete in Class
In class this week, we learned about:

markdown: a very simple “language” for specifying how to format text in a plain-text document.
quarto: a system for interweaving markdown text with R code to produce dynamic documents of various kinds.

In this assignment, you will practice using both of these tools by creating a simple CV written in markdown within a quarto document.

Instructions

In R Studio, create a new quarto document by going to File > New File > Quarto Document…
Give your new document the title “Curriculum Vitae”, and make sure the output format is HTML.
Because the whole point here is to practice writing in Markdown, in R Studio, please make sure that you are using the Source editor rather than the Visual editor (image below).



Delete all the boilerplate text and code under the header (from line 6 in the image above).
Write your CV! And feel free to make stuff up. What to include:

Top-level header should be your name
Include contact info: phone, email, and link to some website (doesn’t matter which).
Include second-level headings for education, employment, publications, and teaching.
Each section should include a bulleted or numbered list of items, or a table.
Highlight years in bold and (possibly fake) journal names in italics
Embed some kind of image at the bottom

Apply a theme to your document. Hint: you will have to change the header slightly.
(Attempt to) submit the .qmd and the rendered .html output file for your completed CV in Canvas.

title: Week 2, Lab 2: Files and Paths
text: Data analysis usually involves loading files into R from your local computer. This does not always go smoothly. In this activity, we’re going to learn how to use paths correctly to avoid some common errors.

title: Week 2, Lab 2: Files and Paths
text:
Absolute Paths
Absolute paths start from the root (top-level) directory of your filesystem and include every step (sub-folder) you must take through the filesystem to reach the target location. The working directory is irrelevant to a properly specified absolute path. In other words, an absolute path points to the same location on a particular computer regardless of your R session’s current working directory.
Examples of made-up absolute paths:

Windows  : "C:\Users\czx412\Documents\deeply\nested\path\that\only\I\can\use\data\my_file.csv"
Mac   / Linux  : "/Users/czx412/Documents/deeply/nested/path/that/only/I/can/use/data/my_file.csv"

Note that absolute paths look different depending on the operating system. In Windows, they start with a drive letter followed by a colon, and in Mac/Linux they start with a forward slash.
Also, for weird historical reasons, paths in Windows traditionally use \, while Unix/Mac use / to separate the folder names. This difference adds an extra complication: \ is a special character in R, which means that the Windows path as written above would not work in R. Fortunately, most apps in Windows (including R) have added support for paths that use /:

Absolute path in Windows    that would work in R: "C:/Users/czx412/Documents/deeply/nested/path/that/only/I/can/use/data/my_file.csv".

You can still write your paths using \ if you’re running R on Windows, but because the single backslash is a special character, you need to use two of them each time:

Absolute path in Windows    that would work in R, as written by the utterly deranged: "C:\\Users\\czx412\\Documents\\deeply\\nested\\path\\that\\only\\I\\can\\use\\data\\my_file.csv".







Caution



The independence of absolute paths from the working directory concept might make you think absolute paths are always the way to go in R. And you’d be wrong. Avoid using absolute paths in R!


Absolute paths are a common source of problems.
Aside from their annoying length, absolute paths don’t work on different computers and tend to break over time. A file that exists in a certain place on your computer right now almost certainly does not exist in that exact same place on someone else’s computer, or on another computer that you use now or in the future. But if you use relative paths (see below) in a consistent way, then they should work other computers, regardless of where the project root directory is located in each different computer’s file system.
Not sharing code with anybody or using multiple computers right at this very moment? Don’t forget future-you! Current-you should should have an interest in helping future-you to work efficiently rather than sabotaging their work by filling your R scripts with what will eventually become broken file paths.

title: Week 2, Lab 2: Files and Paths
text:
Relative Paths
Relative paths are typically far shorter and simpler. A relative path is relative to some assumed starting point, avoiding the need to provide the full, absolute path. For this to work properly, the program needs to know your assumed starting point: our old friend, the working directory.
Here’s an example of a relative path:

Any system: "data/my_file.csv"

Translation: in the working directory, look in a subfolder called "data" for a file called "my_file.csv".
Hence, the relative path "data/my_file.csv" would be interpreted in any R session as simply appending this to the end of the R session’s working directory, which in my case results in:


[1] "/Users/czx412/Documents/Work/UTSA/Teaching/Data Visualization/Data Visualization - Fall 2023/website/assignments/week-02/data/my_file.csv"









Special Characters



There are a few special characters that are useful when using relative paths:

~ is the user’s home directory. On this particular computer, ~ is equivalent to “/Users/czx412”. This will change depending on which computer I’m using.
.. is the parent directory. So the path "../my_file.csv" would refer to a file called "my_file.csv" in the directory that is one level above the working directory.

title: Week 2, Lab 2: Files and Paths
text:
R session vs. Quarto/RMarkdown
Another sneaky source of problems, even when you’re working in a project and using relative paths, can occur when you are reading or writing files from a Quarto document (all of this is also true for R Markdown, but for the sake of brevity, I will only refer to Quarto below).
Specifically, problems often occur when your .qmd file is located somewhere other than your project root folder. And the simple reason is that a Quarto document functions temporarily as its own, self-contained R session while it is rendering. When this happens, the working directory for the rendering document becomes whatever folder the .qmd file lives in, regardless of the working directory in your “main” R session.
If the .qmd file is in the project root folder, there’s no problem, because the working directories for both the R session and rendering document are the same.
But if the .qmd file is located somewhere else—say, in a subfolder of your project, or in some other location entirely—then you can get problems. In such cases, a command to load data using a relative path that runs successfully in your R script (or when executed in your R session from the .qmd file itself) will fail during rending, and vice versa.

title: Week 2, Lab 2: Files and Paths
text:
The ‘here’ package
The here R package was created in part to resolve this problem. It’s very simple and has only one goal: locating files in a project. It will always locate the files relative to your project root folder. When the package is first loaded, you’ll get a message telling you the absolute path to your project root.

library("here")

here() starts at /Users/czx412/Documents/Work/UTSA/Teaching/Data Visualization/Data Visualization - Fall 2023/website


The here() function locates a file relative to your project’s root folder, and converts this behind the scenes into a correct absolute path for whatever computer you’re currently using, regardless of whether it’s used in an R session or while rendering a Quarto document. This is how you use it:

# Specify path to a csv file in project root folder
here("file_i_want.csv")

[1] "/Users/czx412/Documents/Work/UTSA/Teaching/Data Visualization/Data Visualization - Fall 2023/website/file_i_want.csv"

# Specify path to a csv file located in a subfolder called "data" in your project root folder
here("data/file_i_want.csv")

[1] "/Users/czx412/Documents/Work/UTSA/Teaching/Data Visualization/Data Visualization - Fall 2023/website/data/file_i_want.csv"








Note



The file path that you actually provide to the here() function is always a simple relative path. The absolute paths generated by the function will (and should) look different in your document from mine and everyone else’s.


Why would you want to use this? Two main reasons:

The same command will “just work” whether it is run from your console, an R source file, or while rendering a Quarto document.
It is not affected by your fiddling around with setwd() (which I suggest always avoiding if possible). Instead, it will figure out the top level of your current project, and locate the file from there.

We will explore this in more detail in the activity below.

Tip



When reading about ggplot2, especially in older resources, you may come across the function qplot() (for “quick plot”). qplot() a bare-bones, training-wheels alternative to the ggplot() function, and it is far less useful. The package authors have moved away from recommending use this function, which is now deprecated:

“Feedback indicated that qplot() was a crutch: it makes simple plots a little easier, but it doesn’t help with mastering the grammar” (Wickham, 2016, p. viii).

I suggest never using it.

title: Week 4, Lab 1: Baboon activity budgets
text:
Description of data set
These data are drawn from actual observations of wild savanna baboons in the Amboseli basin of southern Kenya. The Amboseli Baboon Research Project is one of the world’s longest-running naturalistic field studies, and in many respects its long-term database is perhaps the largest, most comprehensive, and most consistent for any wild primate. These particular data are a small subset of “point samples” taken at regular intervals during focal sampling of baboons over a 1-year period in 2000.



Baboons in Amboseli, Kenya.

title: ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration
text:
Overview
This course is designed for graduate students in social or natural sciences who would like to gain experience in data visualization and analysis using R. It aims to be accessible to those who are completely new to programming, but also to provide new insights and skills to those who already have experience using R.

title: ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration
text:
Approach
This course will use a mix of traditional and flipped classroom approaches, with new material introduced in reading assignments prior to class while class time will focus on applying those skills to data sets. The course will be activity-focused. Most concepts will be first introduced in assigned readings outside of class, leaving class time to focus on developing practical skills, completing activities, making progress on individual projects. We will cover topics in both data visualization as well as data manipulation. Students are encouraged to work collaboratively in and out of class. The online course schedule provides an overview of the topics covered as well as links to weekly readings, in-class activities, and any lecture material. This schedule is preliminary and always subject to change.

title: ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration
text:

title: Course Policies
text:
Course Information

Course Description
This course introduces theory and practical skills for managing and displaying quantitative information so that visual stories can be found and communicated effectively. We will cover principles of tidy data, strategies for data exploration, and principles of visual presentation. We will use the R computing environment, but no prior programming experience is required. The emphasis is on gaining practical skills that will empower students to answer questions with data.


Course Goals
This course will provide students an opportunity to master theoretical concepts in data visualization and to acquire valuable skills for exploring data and producing statistical graphics. Students will learn how to use R to produce visualizations and work with quantitative data, and to apply these skills to communicate scientific knowledge effectively.


Student Learning Objectives/Outcomes
During this semester, students will have the opportunity to:

Learn fundamental principles and best practices for the visual display of quantitative data.
Become familiar with data input, analysis, and export using the R statistical computing environment.
Achieve proficiency with key R packages for data visualization and exploration.
Develop skills in written and oral communication and graphical display of data through online activities, small group assignments, and individual projects.



Course Prerequisites
There are no prerequisites for this class. In particular, prior programming experience is not required. Some familiarity with quantitative methods and data analysis would be helpful. Students with significant experience in R should still find new things to learn or important knowledge to review in each lesson.


Course Materials
All reading materials will be online or posted to the course website. Assigned readings should be completed before the start of class on the day indicated.


Communication
All lecture notes, assignment instructions, an up-to-date schedule, and other course materials may be found on the course website. Announcements will be emailed through Canvas Announcements periodically. Please check your email regularly to ensure you have the latest announcements for the course.

title: Course Policies
text:
Course Requirements

In-Class Exercises
As a (mostly) flipped classroom, our in-class time will involve brief refreshers on new concepts introduced in the readings followed by working on exercises that relate to those concepts. These exercises will include activities that the instructor will describe in class. While students are working on these exercises, the instructor will actively engage with students to help them understand material that they find confusing, help identify problems that are preventing students from completing the exercises, and discuss novel applications and alternative approaches to the data visualization challenges that students are working to complete.
Assigned in-class exercises can be found under the relevant week of the course schedule.


Small Projects
During the term, there will be two small data visualization projects that each student must complete. The professor will provide a data set and detailed instructions for each project. In brief, the projects will be visualization challenges in which the student will read in the data set in R, produce one or more visualizations of the data, and provide a written narrative (~1000 words) of interesting aspects or insights gained in the process of analyzing the data. The submission should be a Quarto/RMarkdown report in HTML format, and it must include the R code used, the embedded visualizations, and the written narrative. Please also submit the .qmd file used to make the report.


Final Project
For the final project, students are encouraged to find and/or use a data set related to their thesis topic, if possible. If this is not possible, the professor can help to find a data set on a topic relevant to the student’s interests. Students must demonstrate and document both data tidying/preparation and data visualization. Further instructions will be provided. The submitted final project should include:

The raw data set used in the analysis (contact me if there are any concerns about this).
A Quarto/RMarkdown report in HTML format with all R code used, at least 3 plots, and a written narrative of approximately 1000 words.
The .qmd file used to make the report.
A digital poster (in a digital format such as PDF—no actual printed posters please!), similar to what you might present at an academic conference, that presents your project visually.



Attendance and Participation
Regular attendance will be essential to the successful completion of this course. Attendance is mandatory and will count toward your final grade. We are aiming for a supportive and cooperative learning environment. To accomplish this, I expect students to be actively engaged participants in all classroom activities.

title: Course Policies
text:
Grading






Note



It is expected that students will have a wide range of prior experience and abilities. Grading will reflect learning and effort in the course rather than techical ability.


Details of grading scheme can be found in the course syllabus posted to Blackboard. Grades will be assigned using the following weighted components:




Component
Weight




Completion of In-class Exercises
40%


First Small Project
15%


Second Small Project
15%


Final Project
25%


Attendance and Participation
5%




Make-up policy
Late assignments will be penalized 20% and will not be accepted more than 48 hours late except in cases of genuine emergencies that can be documented by the student or in cases where late submission has been discussed and approved in advance.

title: Course Policies
text:
Course Community

Cooperative Learning Environment
I encourage you to discuss the course activities with your friends and classmates as you are working on them. You will learn more in this class if you work with others than if you do not.
However, you should not directly copy code or allow other students to copy your code. When cooperating on a problem, you can discuss it with others, but write your own solutions. Direct copying of code will be considered cheating, and will be subject to the Scholastic Dishonesty policies outlined in the Student Code of Conduct
Share ideas, ask questions, ask for help, but don’t copy.


Code of Conduct
I expect and require behavior compatible with a high standard of scholarship. Refrain from distracting behavior, such as talking during lectures, and wait until class is dismissed before packing up your belongings. Please try not to arrive late or leave early. Most importantly, you must show respect for each other’s opinions and differing levels of prior knowledge and ability.

Course Learning Objectives
By the end of the semester, you will…

learn to explore, visualize, and analyze data in a reproducible and shareable manner
gain experience in data wrangling and munging, exploratory data analysis, predictive modeling, and data visualization work on problems and case studies inspired by and based on real-world questions and data
learn to effectively communicate results through written assignments and final project presentation

title: Syllabus
text:
Course community

Inclusive community
It is my intent that students from all diverse backgrounds and perspectives be well-served by this course, that students’ learning needs be addressed both in and out of class, and that the diversity that the students bring to this class be viewed as a resource, strength, and benefit. It is my intent to present materials and activities that are respectful of diversity and in alignment with Duke’s Commitment to Diversity and Inclusion. Your suggestions are encouraged and appreciated.


Accessibility
If there is any portion of the course that is not accessible to you due to challenges with technology or the course format, please let me know so we can make appropriate accommodations.
The Student Disability Access Office (SDAO) is available to ensure that students are able to engage with their courses and related assignments. Students should be in touch with the Student Disability Access Office to request or update accommodations under these circumstances.


Communication
All lecture notes, assignment instructions, an up-to-date schedule, and other course materials may be found on the course website.
Announcements will be emailed through Sakai Announcements periodically. Please check your email regularly to ensure you have the latest announcements for the course.

title: Syllabus
text:
Activities & Assessment

Labs
In labs, you will apply the concepts discussed in lecture to various data analysis scenarios, with a focus on the computation.


Homework
In homework, you will apply what you’ve learned during lecture and lab to complete data analysis tasks.


Exams
There will be two, take-home, open-note exams. Through these exams you have the opportunity to demonstrate what you’ve learned in the course thus far.


Final Project
The purpose of the final project is to apply what you’ve learned throughout the semester to analyze an interesting data-driven research question.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course policies

Academic honesty
TL;DR: Don’t cheat!
Please abide by the following as you work on assignments in this course:

You may discuss individual homework and lab assignments with other students; however, you may not directly share (or copy) code or write up with other students. For team assignments, you may collaborate freely within your team. You may discuss the assignment with other teams; however, you may not directly share (or copy) code or write up with another team. Unauthorized sharing (or copying) of the code or write up will be considered a violation for all students involved.
You may not discuss or otherwise work with others on the exams.
Reusing code: Unless explicitly stated otherwise, you may make use of online resources (e.g. StackOverflow) for coding examples on assignments. If you directly use code from an outside source (or use it as inspiration), you must explicitly cite where you obtained the code. Any recycled code that is discovered and is not explicitly cited will be treated as plagiarism.



Late work & extensions
The due dates for assignments are there to help you keep up with the course material and to ensure the teaching team can provide feedback within a timely manner. We understand that things come up periodically that could make it difficult to submit an assignment by the deadline. Note that the lowest homework and lab assignment will be dropped to accommodate such circumstances.
